stream_context.summary: Kaze spent most of the session sculpting and texturing giant fruit props for the overworld, tweaking the overworld’s geometry to shorten empty stretches, and discussing recently-fixed Course 6 bugs. He also outlined new travel and accessibility features and touched on upcoming graphical work.

development_findings.summary: Re-importing all Course 6 assets with the current Fast64 exporter removed several long-standing bugs, implying the 2022 conversion was incompatible with the engine.
development_findings.quote: Today I spent all morning re-importing all the assets from course 6 into Mario 64 and somehow that fixed a bunch of bugs with course 6.

development_findings.summary: Large overworld paths are being shortened to eliminate ‘vast empty stretches’ while keeping landmark density high.
development_findings.quote: Maybe this straight here is a little long… we could shorten this, honestly.

development_findings.summary: A new pause-menu world map will let players fast-travel to any level entrance they have already visited, effectively removing back-tracking time.
development_findings.quote: On the map you can select which level entrance you walk to and you can walk to any level entrance that you've entered before, so I'm actually not worried about travel time at all.

development_findings.summary: Giant collectible fruit (banana, apple, strawberry, honey melon, watermelon, grapes, orange) are being modeled; Kaze struggled with orange skin reflections and may switch to a normal-map approach.
An accessibility option will allow players to ‘cheat’ past difficult sections so that less skilled players can finish the game.
development_findings.quote: It's an accessibility option… even bad players can play the game so you can just cheat in this game.

development_findings.summary: Fancy water shaders are planned and the required code is already available.
development_findings.quote: Will you be giving this area fancy water graphics too? Yes. We already have the codes.

development_findings.summary: A day–night cycle was considered but rejected because the design was not planned around it.
development_findings.quote: I do very very much enjoy the night systems but that's something you need to plan the game around. And we did not.

development_findings.summary: Dynamic rope physics exist in the codebase but have not yet been applied to climbable poles; Kaze wants to add them but worries about gameplay feel.
development_findings.quote: We have rope physics already… I just haven't applied them… I'm a bit worried that it's going to feel jank to play with.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is using a newly-discovered Blender UV plugin (found by Biobak) to speed up modeling and texturing tasks.

context_findings.summary: Kaze dislikes ‘item babysitting’ design, calling it ‘game-design morphine’ that is easy for creators but painful for players.
context_findings.quote: Putting missions where you babysit items is like taking morphine… it's an easy way to feel good but it sucks for everyone involved.

context_findings.summary: He views player time as the ultimate resource and designs to minimise wasted travel or grind.
context_findings.quote: The only resource they truly have is their time… as soon as you realise that, Pokémon kind of sucks.

context_findings.summary: He is highly smell-sensitive (vinegar cleaning incident) and emotionally scarred by a bad strawberry-shortcake experience, revealing personal quirks that surface during work.
Expressed satisfaction and renewed emotional attachment as the overworld begins to ‘feel right’.
context_findings.quote: Now that the overworld is starting to look like something I'm starting to feel something for the overworld.

biobak.summary: Provided a Blender UV/vertex tool that Kaze finds ‘insanely convenient’.
biobak.quote: This is a very cool plugin that Biobak found.

badub.summary: Composing the game’s original soundtrack and was present in chat during the session.

zeina.summary: Cleaned the coffee machine with vinegar (personal side note); no project work mentioned in this stream.

key_stories.title: Course 6 Bug Exorcism
key_stories.summary: Old conversion bugs plagued Course 6 until Kaze re-exported every asset with the current Fast64 pipeline. The level suddenly behaved correctly.
key_stories.process: Deleted 2022 exports and re-imported all assets using the latest Fast64 exporter.
key_stories.outcome: Bugs vanished; suggests prior exports were fundamentally incompatible with the engine.
key_stories.key_quote: Somehow that fixed a bunch of bugs with course 6.

key_stories.title: Shrinking the Overworld
key_stories.summary: Play-testing revealed walkways that felt empty and slow. Kaze shortened corridors and plans fast-travel via the pause-menu map to keep pacing tight.
key_stories.challenge: Overworld traversal felt long and empty.
key_stories.process: Cut straight paths, added 90-degree turn corridors, designed map-select teleportation.
key_stories.outcome: Leaned overworld geometry and removed concern about travel time.
key_stories.key_quote: I'm actually not worried about travel time at all; I'm just worried about vast empty stretches of land.

key_stories.title: The Impossible Orange
key_stories.summary: Kaze spent significant time trying to texture a realistic orange with reflections, fought with N64 combiner limits, and may switch to normal mapping.
key_stories.challenge: Achieving convincing orange-skin texture within N64 limitations.
key_stories.process: Experimented with reflection combiners, searched for seamless pores textures, attempted sphere projection UVs.
key_stories.outcome: Temporarily accepted a placeholder texture; considering abandoning reflections for normal mapping.
key_stories.key_quote: Dude, I can't make a fucking orange… oh well, this is what it's gonna be for now.
